name: GJ 1132
scenarioDescription:
The GJ 1132 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 1132 is a star with 0.18 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.21 times its radius. It is located 41.1608872 light years away from the solar system.

GJ 1132 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 1132 system

GJ 1132 b

GJ 1132 b was discovered by the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory observatory using the Transit method. The mass of GJ 1132 b is 1.66 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 1132 b is 1.13 that of Earth. At 1.66 Earth masses, GJ 1132 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


GJ 1132 c

GJ 1132 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the Radial Velocity method.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 1132, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory.
